channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl Developer and Business Owner? Remote Perl role in UK & EU
item.description: Our clients run a job search engine that has grown from two friends with an idea to a site that receives more than 10 million visits per month. They're looking for a Perl pro with at least three years of experience with high-volume and high-traffic apps and sites, has a solid understanding of Object-Oriented Perl (perks if that knowledge includes Moose), SQL/MySQL and DBIx::Class.

item.title: Perl to Node Cross-training? Yes Please! UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you. You’ll be deploying apps your work to AWS, so experience would be handy, and the company’s big on testing, so they’d like you to know your way around Test::More.

item.title: Perl Superheroes Wanted! Remote Perl within US time zone
item.description: Our client is looking for a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBIx::Class, and you should have a few solid years of commercial experience under your belt. Best of all, this position is 100% remote within the US and similar time zones.

item.title: Bold, beautiful, and… brainy? Senior Perl roles in Malaysia, Dubai and Malta
item.description: Our client provides online trading services and with offices in Dubai, Malta, and Malaysia, they’ve got the global reach that may provide the challenge you’re looking for. Their staff count has increased 600 percent in the last four years, and growth is still on the upswing. They know that a seasoned Perl pro is just what their team needs as they expand, and that’s where you come in.

item.title: Boston PM : Ovid+LeoNerd on Corinna - OO in Perl5 Core (live but virtual)
item.description: Tuesday Oct 11th, 2022 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Office Hours - Charlotte PM co-host with Charlotte Python; in-person only, Optimist Hall
item.description: Wednesday, Sept 28, 2022; 06:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: Go course
item.description: Two parts of a short Go course was published.

item.title: Git on Windows
item.description: All 10 parts of the existing short series were published.

item.title: Programming Boootcamp for Scientists
item.description: The 2nd part of the Programming Boootcamp for Scientists was published

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: PWC 182
item.description: I just loved the one-liner in Perl, Raku and Julia. Thorough task analysis of Common Path task is worth checking out.

item.title: Max is Common
item.description: Roger always shares fixed set of solutions. Not only that but we also get to know the fun facts about each language. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Find the biggest and the deepest
item.description: Story telling narrative of weekly task is irresistable. Thanks for everything.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 182
item.description: Great use of CPAN module to solve the weekly tasks. Highly recommended.

item.title: max and containing paths
item.description: Compact Raku solutions with detailed analysis. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 182: Max Index and Common Path
item.description: Once again we got the collection of solutions. Cool collections that you really don't want to miss out.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge 182
item.description: James is known for compact solutions. Plenty to learn from his cool work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 182
item.description: Jaldhar's Raku solution is my favourite of all time, very elegant. Highly recommended.

item.title: PWC182 - Common Path
item.description: Use of CPAN module for Perl solution makes it compact. For Raku, everything is part of the core language. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC182 - Max Index
item.description: Descriptive solutions in Perl and Raku with a touch of sweet history. Well done.

item.title: Just Your Garden-Variety Path
item.description: Great show of Perl regex to deal with Common Path task. Thanks for your support and contributions.

item.title: The Common Index
item.description: Arne has been generous and sharing bonus Perl solutions alongwith Raku. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Deepest Common Index
item.description: Adam breaking down the task into smaller actions and dealt with each makes it easy to follow. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 182
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Max Index" and "Common Path" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 183
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks: "Unique Array" and "Date Difference". If you are new to the weekly challenge, why not join us and have fun every week? For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Type::Tiny v2 is Coming
item.description: Type::Tiny v2 is intended to be compatible with Type::Tiny v1. Thorough detailed discussion about the changes.

item.title: Cryptopals 27 - Recover the key from CBC with IV=Key
Cryptopals 28 - Implement a SHA-1 keyed MAC
Cryptopals 29 - Break a SHA-1 keyed MAC using length extension
Cryptopals 30 - Break an MD4 keyed MAC using length extension
How does SPVM resolve the problems of Perl numeric operations?
item.description: Do you know SPVM? If not then please do checkout an interesting usecase.

item.title: An artistic tool for programmers
item.description: Release of App::GUI::Harmonograph makes it fun and easy to create an art.

item.title: Hacktoberfest 2022 is near!
item.description: Nice introduction and peek into the annual event of opensource hacking. Please do checkout if you are interested.

item.title: #582 - Grandfather’s Perl
item.description:
Hi there,

Few months ago, there was a blog post Why Perl is still relevant in 2022 created a lot of noise among the Perl community. The author clearly missed the point. If you check the comments section, you can see how, White Camel Awardee, Dave Cross and few others responed to the post.

I was pleasantly surprised when I found out that Dave came up with perfect response to the other blog post with this This is not your grandfather’s Perl. It has already created positive noise. If you want to take a closer look at the recent changes to the latest release of Perl v5.36 then please do checkout the GitHub repository sharing the changes with example. By the way, it is not just limited to v5.36. You will find plenty more to keep you busy.

Talking about Perl, we got another gem from Curtis Poe sharing the Current Corinna Status. If you can't wait for Corinna, I would suggest you take a look at CPAN module Object::Pad by Paul Evans.

Last but not the least, today, Monday 19 September, the date of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II's State Funeral declared as National Bank Holiday. Please checkout the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: editorial
